title: Ecologies of Violence: Crimes against Nature in the Contemporary Cultural Imagination
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Ecologies of Violence: Crimes against Nature in the Contemporary Cultural Imagination," seeks to develop an innovative ecological model for studying violence and its representation in cultural expressions. The objectives of this project include documenting how cultural expressions depict ecoviolence, mapping the connections between ecoviolence, colonialism, and genocide, and analyzing reflections on guilt, responsibility, and culture's involvement in violence.

Using methods such as comparative study and transnational analysis, this project will integrate cultural memory studies and ecocriticism to create a comprehensive study of environmental violence in culture. The project will also produce a best practices guide for pedagogy engagement with cultural representations of ecoviolence.

The key themes of this project include environmental violence, cultural memory, ecocriticism, representation of violence, and critical literacies about ecoviolence. By exploring how representations harness affect and emotion for environmental crisis relation and critical self-reflection, this project aims to reorient cultural memory research and ecocriticism to consider more-than-human terms.

Overall, "Ecologies of Violence: Crimes against Nature in the Contemporary Cultural Imagination" will provide a framework for thinking about violence and memory in a broader ecological context, contributing valuable insights to the field of cultural studies.
